titleStmt.title: East L.A. Walkouts at Abraham Lincoln High School
titleStmt.author: Michelle Rolon

div.p: Abraham Lincoln High School is a historic platform of the early Chicano Movement due to strong student activism in the 1968 East L.A. Blowouts. Because of the hostile and racist education sector towards Mexican Americans students, the East Los Angeles community united to create demands for the Board of Education. The demands included integration of ethnic studies classes and better school facilities (Garcia). After the demands were ignored, Sal Castro, a teacher from Lincoln High, and other community leaders became involved to organize student walkouts in different schools from East L.A. (Watanabe). In March, more than 2,000 students from five schools began to peacefully walk out of their campuses in protest. Students were immediately met with violent beatings via police officers, but this did not interrupt the walkouts. On March 28, 1,200 people attended the community meeting at Lincoln High where the demands were brought forth to the Board (Contreras).

note.p: Abraham Lincoln High School is a historic platform of the Chicano Movement due to strong student activism in the 1968 East L.A. Blowouts.
